instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message:
The board has a fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.

The EN lines are unstable too. If I heat the PCH I get a fan spin, but am not sure if I am actually affecting something else....

Anyone with experience know if it's a PCH issue or if there is a component near by I am helping when heating the PCH?

Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message: It's power cycling. Was this liquid? Look carefully around clock chip area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message:
The board looks very (too) clean and I suspect there may have been liquid damage.

Do you mean to look around Y5010?
It looks very clean and tidy there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message: No, did you even look at the diagram? <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> is clock chip. Measure voltage peaks on Y2605 pins, need to know the highest value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Clock "Chip" hmm, I was looking for a crystal.

Y2605::3 : 1.3v Highest. But usually around 200 - 300mV
Y2605::1 : is a round 8mV.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message:
That seems ok. No signs of corrosion in <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> area?
Is CPU Vcore pulsing too? Check <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/3 for corrosion.
Any history on this machine? Usually they don't "just" stop working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/3 look ok.

Can't see any corrosion near <CHIP>U2600</CHIP>, but if I heat it up it boots every time. :/

Customer told me it just stopped working, but I can see liquid damage / sediment around the <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_RTC</SIGNAL> stable at every probe/Via? 

To me it sounds like there could be a duff trace that reconnects when it heats up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message: Boots as in it chimes and works?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message:
I only have a screen plugged in; so boots as in backlight and grey screen.
It doesn't get much further, I think, because the board cools down too much.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message: I'll check when I get to the office.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message: Just to clarify, which two caps?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message: The ones on the Xtal lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message: Look at diagram at <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> and don't tell me you can't figure it out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message: Duke, when board is power cycling And 3V And 5V are pulsing, this is usually problem with chip clock?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light, no fan spin.
threads.message: Don't hijack thread. Cycling power can be caused by anything.
